subject: Google’s Latest Update: Starve the SEOs, and a Funeral for the Open Web
preview: Five prompts, 100 images. Meanwhile, the web is simultaneously growing and dying, depending on which Google you ask.                         Welcome to That's WasSERP Issue #8 In this episode, Google

full_threads.body:
Five prompts, 100 images. Meanwhile, the web is simultaneously growing and dying, depending on which Google you ask.

Welcome to That's WasSERP Issue #8

In this episode, Google has capped your inputs and can't decide whether the web you work in is alive or dead. Your job this week is to adapt and start planning for a search ecosystem where you get less to work with and fewer places to send it.

Let's get this (horror) show on the road.

**

Hunger Games, But For SEO: Inside Google's New Rations

Five prompts a day, one hundred images, and five Deep Research reports a month. These are Gemini's new caps in effect.

On paper, that's a product spec. In practice, it's a slow but steady strangulation of your content pipeline. Here's where the rationing hits hardest:

Images (100 per day, free tier)

  • Listicles: A "50 AI Tools You Should Try This Week" post can easily burn 50-80 images if you want unique visuals per tool.
  • Blog posts: A steady publishing calendar of three to five posts/day with a few featured images each, and you'll slam into the wall before mid-afternoon.
  • Social content: Each LinkedIn/Twitter/X/Threads post with two to three branded images eats into the quota. Your blog or your social: pick one.

Prompts (5/day free, 100-500 on paid)

  • Brainstorming titles & metas: A single content calendar session can chew through 5-10 prompts. If you're freeloading, you're done before coffee.
  • Long-form articles: Drafting and iterating on one 2,000-word blog can easily consume 20+ prompts. You're not doing it on Free. You may scrape by on Pro.
  • Agency workflows: If you're producing deliverables for multiple clients, you'll hit limits even on Pro unless you upgrade to Ultra.

Deep Research (5/month free, 20/day Pro, 200/day Ultra)

  • Competitive analysis: Free tier gives you five chances on your monthly keyword and SERP reports. That's one client report per week.
  • Content gaps: Agencies running audits for 10-20 clients will outgrow Pro in a jiffy. Ultra becomes less "premium" and more "bare minimum."

What This Means for Publishers

  • Freelancers & solo bloggers: Free tier is hobby-only. Anything beyond journaling gets bottlenecked.
  • Content farms: Do you burn quotas on roundup posts, on Reddit scraping, or on AI-generated "People Also Ask" fodder? You can't do it all, so, triage.
  • Agencies: Client expectations don't scale down because Google capped your prompts. Paid plans are now a line item in the SEO budget.
  • Social-heavy brands: Image caps collide with content velocity. Brands running multi-platform campaigns won't make it past Tuesday on the free tier.

The Web Is Thriving. Wait, It's Dying.

Google swears up and down at I/O that the web is thriving. Four months later, in court, it argues the open web is in "rapid decline." Which is it? Both, apparently.

If the web is growing (PR version): there are more pages, more competition, more AI-churned content. Ranking gets harder. If the open web is shrinking (legal version): ad dollars vanish, publishers cut output, and there's less linking diversity to go around.


What It Means in Practice

  • Link building: Fewer publishers means fewer natural links. Outreach targets may dry up, forcing you into partnerships, PR stunts, or paying through the nose.
  • Content strategy: Publishers reliant on open-web ads may scale back SEO-friendly long-form. Expect more paywalls and affiliate-heavy posts.
  • Budgets: If ad spend shifts to retail media and CTV, marketing chiefs may trim "organic" budgets first. You'll need airtight ROI proof.
  • SERP real estate: AI Overviews and zero-click features will absorb demand. Even if the "web is bigger," you'll see less traffic.

What You Can Actually Do

  • Diversify traffic sources: Start treating SEO as one channel in a multi-channel mix. Push clients into newsletters, social capture, even WhatsApp groups.
  • Rethink link strategy: Start relationships with niche publishers before they vanish or wall up.
  • Track referral sources: Watch how much of your traffic is coming from AI surfaces (Overviews, Perplexity, etc.). That's your future "rankings."
  • Set client expectations: "We're playing inside Google's contradictions. Traffic may be up, revenue may be down. Plan budgets accordingly."


In other words: Google's open web is both alive and dying. Your job is to hedge, because whichever story Google is telling this week, your KPIs will feel the decline.

**

NO-BS Housekeeping Edition

This week's 60-second SEO chore: Polish the H1

If the H1 is garbage, Google and humans read that as "this page doesn't deserve attention." A single sharp H1 improves UX, CTR, and the page's topical clarity. Here's how to fix this:

  1. Open the page you care about. (Pick a high-traffic or conversion page if you're greedy with results.)
  2. Find the H1

    • Fastest: Right-click → Inspect and hit Ctrl+F → type <h1.
    • Alternative: Ctrl+U (view source) then Ctrl+F → <h1.

  3. Ask two quick questions

    • Does an H1 exist? If no, create one. If yes, continue.
    • Is it unique & meaningful? If it's "Welcome", "Home", or exactly duplicates the <title>, mark it as bad.

  4. Fix it
    • Replace bland/duplicate H1 with a single-line, user-first headline that:

      • Puts the primary keyword early (but naturally).
      • Adds one benefit/clarifier (why click/read).
      • Keeps it concise (think 4-10 words; if you must, up to ~12).

    • Quick templates: 
      • For how-to / guides: How to [ACTION] - [Benefit]
        e.g., How to Fix H1s That Boost Clicks
      • For product pages: [PRODUCT NAME] - [#1 Benefit / USP]
        e.g., QuietPulse Grinder - Fast, Low Noise, Built to Last
      • For category pages: [KEYWORD] for [AUDIENCE] - [Promise]
        e.g., Budget Laptops for Students - 8 Picks Under $500

Edit the H1 in your CMS, Save/Draft, then refresh the live page and re-inspect to confirm <h1> changed. If your site uses JS rendering, confirm in the rendered DOM (Inspect → Elements).

**

Quote of the Week

"Five prompts a day keeps the SEO strategy away."

- Word For The Wise

And that's Wasserp in search this week. See you at Nine.
